title: Reforming Our Incarceration System To Eliminate the Use of Privately Operated Criminal Detention Facilities

enrichment.summary: This executive order directs the federal government to stop using privately run prisons for criminal detention, aiming to reduce the role of profit in incarceration and ensure safer, more rehabilitative prison conditions. It requires the Attorney General not to renew contracts with private detention facilities, promoting a justice system focused on rehabilitation and humane treatment.
potential_concerns: Phasing out private detention facilities may lead to capacity challenges in federal prisons if alternative arrangements are not adequately planned.
Closing contracts with private facilities could increase costs for the federal government if publicly operated prisons require expansion or additional resources.
There may be legal or contractual disputes from private prison operators over non-renewal of contracts.
Transitioning from private to federal facilities may face implementation delays that affect detainee welfare and system efficiency.
Critics might argue that simply ending private contracts does not fully address systemic issues of mass incarceration or racial disparities in the justice system.
